10.1016/j.mcat.2021.112063 Fig. 1 XRD patterns. (a) MCM-41-supported metal oxide catalysts. (b) metal oxide catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Co 2p3/2 XPS spectra. (b) Mn 2p3/2 XPS spectra. (c) TEM image of the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Catalytic performance of different catalysts for the production of toluene intermediate. Reaction conditions: 5 g xylan, 15 g catalyst, 5 g methanol, 580 °C. HZ: HZSM-5(25). Others: oxygenated compounds such as furans and acids. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Effect of xylan/methanol mass ratio on the production of toluene intermediate. Conditions: 5 g xylan, 15 g 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst, 580 °C. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Effect of temperature on the production of toluene intermediate. Conditions: 5 g xylan, 5 g methanol, 15 g 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Effect of temperature on toluene oxidation to benzoic acid. Conditions: 1.0 g toluene, 0.1 g 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst, 0.02 g n-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI), 4 h. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Effect of reaction time on toluene oxidation to benzoic acid. Conditions: 1.0 g toluene, 0.1 g 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst, 0.02 g NHPI, 80 °C. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Effect of oxidants on toluene oxidation to benzoic acid. Conditions: 1.0 g toluene, 0.1 g 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41, 0.02 g NHPI, 80 °C, 4 h. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Catalytic oxidation of two xylan-derived intermediates with the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst. (a) Aromatic intermediate (1#) was derived from xylan catalytic pyrolysis over 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst at 580 °C. (b) Aromatic intermediate (2#) was obtained by the distillation of sample-1#. Conditions for catalytic oxidation: 1.0 g substrate, 0.1 g catalyst, 0.02 g NHPI, 80 °C, 4 h. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Stability of catalysts in the synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid. (a) Yield of toluene intermediate in the catalytic pyrolysis/regeneration cycles (reaction conditions: 5 g xylan, 5 g methanol, 15 g 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst, 580 °C, 0.5 h for each cycle; regeneration conditions: 600 °C, 100 ml/min O2, 3 h). (b) TGA profiles of three samples (fresh 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst; used catalyst for the catalytic pyrolysis at 580 °C for 1.5 h; regenerated catalyst). (c) Stability of catalysts in the catalytic oxidation (conditions: 1.0 g intermediate 2#, 0.1 g 10wt% Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst, 80 °C, 4 h for each cycle). (d) XRD profiles of fresh 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst and used one for the catalytic oxidation at 80 °C for 20 h. The efficient synthesis of bio-based chemicals using renewable carbon resources is of great significance to promote sustainable chemistry and develop green economy. This work aims to demonstrate that benzoic acid, an important high added value chemical in petrochemical industry, can be selectively synthesized using xylan (a typical model compound of hemicellulose). This novel controllable transformation process was achieved by selective catalytic pyrolysis of xylan and subsequent catalytic oxidation. The highest benzoic acid selectivity of 88.3 % with 90.5 % conversion was obtained using the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions (80 °C, 4 h). Based on the study of the model compounds and catalyst's characterizations, the reaction pathways for the catalytic transformation of xylan to bio-based benzoic acid were proposed. Graphical abstract Selective catalytic synthesis of bio-based high value chemical of benzoic acid was achieved by the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan over the ZnO/HZSM-5 catalyst and the catalytic oxidation over the Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst. Lignocellulose biomass is the most plentiful renewable carbon resource, which is typically made up of 30∼50 wt% cellulose, 20∼40 wt% hemicellulose and 15%∼25 wt% lignin [4]. To date, the synthesis of bio-based chemicals using lignocellulose biomass or its derivatives has aroused a great concern [4–7]. To utilize lignocellulose effectively, it is very important to design reaction pathways according to its unique composition and structure. Hemicellulose is one of the three main components of lignocellulosic biomass [4]. Hemicellulose is a heteropolymer composed of several different monosaccharides (like xylose, rhamnose, galactose, mannose and arabinose), which the most abundant monomer in hemicellulose is xylose [4]. In general, xylan is used as a typical model compound to study the catalytic conversion of hemicellulose into high-value chemicals [8–11]. The catalytic pyrolysis of xylan is a promising way to produce various aromatics, usually using the zeolite catalysts [8–10]. For the reaction pathway of xylan to aromatics, xylan is initially decomposed into oxygenated compounds such as acids, aldehydes and ketones [8,10]. Then, the oxygen-containing compounds derived from the pyrolysis of xylan can be catalytically converted to aromatic hydrocarbons through a series of reactions, such as decarboxylation, decarbonylation, aromatization and polymerization [8,10]. The yield of aromatics from the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan with the HZSM-5 catalyst is lower than that from cellulose [9]. It has been reported that the co-catalytic pyrolysis of xylan and low-density polyethylene (LDPE) promoted the yield of aromatics due to the increase of the effective hydrogen to carbon ratio in the reaction system [8,10]. Besides aromatics, xylan can be also used to synthesize other high-value chemicals [11–14]. It has been demonstrated that selective synthesis of furans (like furan, 2-methylfuran and 2,5-dimethylfuran) can be realized by the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan over the Pt-based bimetallic catalysts [11]. The hydrolysis of xylan or hemicellulose can produce furfural, and the further hydrogenation of furfural can form bio-based 2-methylfuran [12]. Recently, the sulfonated carbon-based catalyst has been proved as an effective catalyst for the production of furfural from xylan in the microwave-assisted biphasic reactions, with 42 % of furfural yield [13]. The selective transformation of xylan to 3-acetyl-1-propanol has been reported by using Ru/H-beta as a high activity bifunctional catalyst [14]. Moreover, the catalytic conversion of hemicellulose or fructose to high-value chemical of methyl lactate has been proved by using the Nb/HUSY catalyst [15]. However, to our knowledge, there was little report on the selective conversion of xylan or hemicellulose to toluene. The selective oxidation of hydrocarbons to produce high value-added products has great significance in the organic synthesis and chemical industry [16–21]. The catalytic oxidation of toluene can produce the products of benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde and benzoic acid [18–21]. Benzoic acid, an important high value-added chemical, is primarily utilized for the synthesis of drugs, dyes, sodium benzoate, plasticizers, fungicides and spices [18]. Currently, benzoic acid is mainly produced by the catalytic oxidation of toluene in acetic acid solution using cobalt salts as a homogeneous catalyst and bromide as an initiator [20]. The major drawbacks in this syntheses process are high energy consumption, the formation of hazardous waste, the problems of product separation and catalyst recovery [21]. Generally, the selectivity and yield of a special product (like benzoic acid or benzaldehyde) in the toluene catalytic oxidation are strongly dependent upon the catalysts and the oxidation reaction parameters [18–21]. Up to present, different catalysts have been investigated for the toluene oxidation, such as metal complexes catalysts [22–24], metallic oxide catalysts [25,26], zeolite catalysts [18,27]. For the homogeneous catalytic process, the oxidation of toluene often leads to higher toluene conversion, but there are problems of product separation and catalyst recovery [18]. On the other hand, the heterogeneous catalysis is preferred owing to the easy separation of catalysts from the products compared to the homogeneous catalysis [18–21]. Improving the selectivity and yield of the target product has great importance for the heterogeneous catalysis oxidation of alkyl aromatics. To date, there was little report on the selective synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid using xylan or hemicellulose, as far as we know. The synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid is still a challenging subject, because the products derived from the catalytic conversion of xylan (or hemicellulose) are usually very complex [8,10]. In this work, we report a novel synthetic strategy of bio-based benzoic acid using xylan as a typical model compound of hemicellulose. Selective synthesis of benzoic acid was achieved by the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan to toluene intermediate over the ZnO/HZSM-5(525) catalyst and the subsequent catalytic oxidation to benzoic acid over the Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst. Co-catalytic conversion of xylan/methanol is beneficial to improve the molar ratio of hydrogen to carbon in the raw material and increase the yield of aromatics. Both xylan and methanol can produce toluene and the yield of toluene from the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan is lower than that from methanol. To understand the synthesis process of benzoic acid from xylan, the catalytic performance of different catalysts, optimization of reaction conditions and catalyst's reusability, have been investigated in detail. The reaction pathways were proposed according to the study on the model compounds and catalyst's characterizations. Potentially, this transformation may offer a useful way for the development of high value chemical of benzoic acid using xylan. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials In present work, xylan was selected as the typical model compound of hemicellulose for the synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid, which was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Shanghai Trading Co,.Ltd (Shanghai, China). The xylan's elemental compositions are made up of 42.46 wt% carbon, 5.88 wt% hydrogen, 51.53 wt% oxygen, 0.02 wt% sulfur and 0.11 wt% nitrogen. Xylan was dried at 110 °C for five hours before each experiment. The other analytical reagents (like methanol, benzene, toluene, p-xylene, methylnaphthalene) used were ordered from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The ZnO-doped zeolite catalysts (like ZnO/HZSM-5(25) with SiO2/Al2O3 mole ratio of 25) were synthesized by the hydrothermal method [28]. The zeolites were obtained from the catalyst company of Nankai University (Tianjin, China). The typical synthesis steps for the 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst were described as follows. Firstly, 1.15 g Zn(NO3)2•6H2O was added to the mixed solution, which contained 50 ml deionized water, 12 ml ethanol, 0.6 g cetyltrimethylamine bromide (CTAB) and 30 ml ammonia water (25 wt%). 10 g HZSM-5(25) was added to the mixed solution (pH∼9.0), and stirred for five hours at 25 °C. Then, the solution was reacted in the stainless steel autoclave (180 °C, 10 h). As cooled to 25 °C, the precipitate was washed using ethanol/deionized water, and then dried at 120 °C for twelve hours. Eventually, the precipitate was calcined in air at 550 °C for five hours. The catalyst powder was noted as 3wt%ZnO/HZSM5(25) catalyst, with a typical mass percentage of 3.04 wt%ZnO. Similarly, the Ga2O3 and Fe2O3-doped zeolite catalysts were prepared by the hydrothermal method using gallium nitrate and ferric nitrate as the Ga and Fe sources, respectively. The different MCM-41-supported single metal oxide catalysts (Co3O4@MCM-41, Mn3O4@MCM-41, Fe2O3@MCM-41 and V2O5@MCM-41) were also synthesized by the hydrothermal method. For instance, the 10wt%Co3O4@MCM41 catalyst was prepared as follows. Firstly, 4.3 g cobaltous nitrate (Co(NO3)2•6H2O) was added to the mixing solution, which contained 50 ml deionized water, 12 ml ethanol, 0.6 g cetyltrimethylamine bromide (CTAB) and 30 ml ammonia water (25 wt%). The MCM-41 supporter of 10 g was added to the mixing solution (pH∼9.0), and stirred for 5 h at 25 °C. Then, the solution was reacted in the stainless steel autoclave (180 °C, 10 h). When it was cooled to 25 °C, the precipitate was washed with ethanol/deionized water and dried at 110 °C for twelve hours. Eventually, the precipitate was calcined at 550 °C in air for five hours, and the resulting powder was noted as 10wt%Co3O4@MCM41 catalyst, with a typical mass percentage of 10.2 wt% Co3O4. Similarly, other metal oxide catalysts (like Mn3O4@MCM41, Fe2O3@MCM41, V2O5@MCM41) were prepared by the same hydrothermal method using corresponding metal nitrates as raw materials. For the bimetallic metal oxide catalyst of 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41, the synthesis process was described as follows. Firstly, 2.95 g cobaltous nitrate (Co(NO3)2•6H2O) and 1.26 g manganous nitrate (Mn(NO3)2•4H2O) were added to the mixing solution, which contained 50 ml deionized water, 12 ml ethanol, 0.6 g cetyltrimethylamine bromide (CTAB) and 30 ml ammonia water (25 wt%). The MCM-41 supporter of 10 g was added to the mixing solution (pH∼9.0), and stirred for 5 h at 25 °C. Then, the solution was reacted in the stainless steel autoclave (180 °C, 10 h). When it was cooled to 25 °C, the precipitate was washed with ethanol/deionized water and dried at 110 °C for twelve hours. Eventually, the precipitate was calcined at 550 °C in air for five hours. The catalyst powder was noted as the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst, with a typical mass percentage of 10.5 wt% Co2MnO4 (Co/Mn molar ratio ∼2:1). 2.3 Catalyst characterization In order to analyze the catalyst's crystal phase, X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were gained by using an XRD diffractometer (Philips-PW3040, Netherlands) [29]. XRD patterns were obtained using the Cu K radiation (0.15406 nm, 45 kV, 40 mA), which were scanned in the range of 10o < 2θ < 80o. The assignments of the XRD patterns were based on the JCPDS files (Joint committee on powder diffraction standards). The state of metal elements on the catalyst surface was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which were conducted by using ESCALab/220iXL spectrometer with an Al-Kα X-ray source (Kratos Analytical-Ltd., UK). The C1s spectrum with the binding energy of 284.6 eV was used for the calibration. The specific surface area and the pore volume were analyzed by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms with a COULTER SA-3100 analyzer (Krefeld, Germany). The elemental analysis was conducted using inductively-coupled plasma & atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Thermo-Jarrell Ash Corporation, USA). The catalyst's acidity and characteristics were tested based on NH3-TPD (ammonia temperature-programmed desorption, scanning range of 100–700 °C, 10 °C/min) [30]. Thermogravimetric-analysis (TGA) for the fresh and used catalysts was analyzed by a Mettler Toledo TGA/DTA 851e analyzer (Switzerland) under the typical conditions: temperature scanning range (25–800 °C), oxygen flow (100 mL min−1) and heating rate (10 °C/min). TEM (Transmission electron microscopy) images were obtained by using JEM2100 microscope (JEOL Ltd.,Tokyo, Japan). 2.4 Experimental procedure for production of toluene intermediate Initially, the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan was performed to produce aromatic intermediates (especially toluene) using different zeolite catalysts in the first step. The catalytic pyrolysis experiments were conducted in the fixed-bed reactor, and the procedure was the same as our previous work [31]. In short, this reaction system was principally made up a tubular reactor (inner diameter: 3 cm, length: 30 cm), a solid reactant feeder, a liquid reactant injection pump, condenser and product analysis instruments. The reactor was installed vertically, in which 5 cm3 of silica sand was added into the pyrolysis zone on the reactor's upper layer and 15 g catalyst was filled in the reactor's lower layer. Firstly, the reactor was flushed for two hours with N2 gas (100 mL min−1), and heated to the setting temperature. Then, the xylan (5 g) was fed to the reactor with 10 g/h feed rate. For the co-catalytic cracking of xylan/methanol, TS260 liquid syringe pump (Baoding, China) was used to feed methanol at the same feed rate. The typical reaction conditions for the catalytic pyrolysis experiments were the mass ratio of catalyst/xylan (3:1), the mass ratio of xylan/methanol (1:1) and temperature (580 °C). For the product analysis and the catalytic reaction evaluation, the gas products were measured with the gas-chromatograph (GCSP689, TCD/FID detectors, Shandonglunan Co., Ltd., China). The liquid products were measured with GC-MS (ThermoTrace GC/ISQ MS, Thermo/Fisher Scientific, USA). The internal standard method was used to determine the content and moles of main products. The yield and selectivity of the products were assessed, as described in our previous work [30,31]. 2.5 Experimental procedure for synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid To produce bio-based benzoic acid, subsequently, the catalytic oxidation of the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates (or aromatic model compounds) was performed with different metal oxide catalysts in the second step. The heterogeneous catalysis reactions were conducted in a 50 mL round bottom flask, typically containing 1.0 g substrate and 0.1 g catalyst. Oxygen was used as a green oxidant in the catalytic oxidation of the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates. The typical reaction conditions for the catalytic oxidation tests were: catalyst/substrate mass ratio (1:10), oxygen flow (50 mL min−1), n-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI)/substrate mass ratio (1:50), temperature (80 °C) and time (4 h). After the reactions for a setting reaction time, the reaction products were cooled to 25 °C, and separated the catalysts from the mixture by high-speed centrifugation. Subsequently, the low boiling point products were analyzed using GC-MS (ThermoTrace GC/ISQMS, USA). Furthermore, the high boiling point products were re-dissolved in the methanol/dimethyl sulfoxide mixed solution. These products were analyzed by the LC10A high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Shimadzu, Japan), with a UV detector at 252 nm. Typically, the mobile phase was made up of the aqueous phase (containing 0.1 wt % phosphoric acid) and the organic phase (containing 70 vol% acetonitrile and 30 vol % methanol), and set the total flow rate at 1 mL/min. The internal standardization method was employed for the quantitative analysis of products. The conversion of reactants, product's selectivity and product's yield were assessed according to the following Eqs. (1)–(3) [32]. (1) C ( % ) = Carbon moles of substrate fed in − Carbon moles of substrate in products Carbon moles of substrate fed in × 100 (2) S i ( % ) = Carbon moles in a product Carbon moles in all products × 100 (3) Y l ( % ) = Carbon moles in a product Carbon moles in substrate × 100 All tests were repeated three times, and the reported data was the average values of three tests. The carbon balance and/or the standard deviation were analyzed to evaluate the experimental precision. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts In this work, two types of catalysts (the acid catalysts of oxides-modified zeolites and the MCM-41 supported metal oxide catalysts) were prepared for the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan and the subsequent catalytic oxidation, respectively. Main properties of the catalysts prepared are summarized in Table 1 . The XRD pattern of the oxides-modified HZSM-5 catalyst (like 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25)) showed very similar diffraction to that of the unmodified zeolite catalyst (Fig. A1 in Supplementary Material). The characteristic peaks (2θ = 23.1°, 29.9°, 45.6° and 66.9°) were attributed to the MFI structure of the HZSM-5(25) zeolite [28]. No diffraction peak associated with ZnO was identified in the 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) sample. This may suggest that the doped species may exist on the outer surface or the pore wall of the zeolites in the form of amorphous or well dispersed particles [28]. As shown in Fig. A2 in Supplementary Material, the SEM analysis confirmed the existence of the doped element of Zn in the 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst, and further ascertains the uniform dispersion of ZnO on the zeolite of HZSM-5(25). As shown in Fig. A3 in Supplementary Material, the NH3-TPD profiles for the unmodified HZSM5 and the zinc oxide modified HZSM5 catalysts showed two distinct characteristic patterns (around 250 °C and 400 °C), which was assigned to NH3 desorption from the weak acid site and strong acid site respectively [28]. The total acidity of the oxides-doped zeolite was slightly lower than the value of the parent zeolite (Table 1). Besides, the specific surface area and the pore volume of the ZnO-doped zeolite catalyst reduced compared to the parent zeolite (Table A1), suggesting that the partial pores could be blocked by loading oxides [33]. For the MCM-41-supported metal oxide catalysts (Fig. 1 a), the XRD patterns showed the prominent characteristic profiles around 2θ = 23.5o, corresponding to the MCM-41 supporter [34]. When the loading amount of the metal oxide was 10 wt%, the XRD diffraction peaks related to metal oxides in the MCM-41-supported metal oxide catalysts were weak. To reveal the active components of the catalysts, the XRD characterizations were employed to analyze the unsupported metal oxide catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1b, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 19.0°, 31.5°, 36.9°, 44.9°, 55.6°, 59.5° and 65.2° for the cobalt oxide catalyst were assigned to the cubic spinel phases of Co3O4 [35]. The manganese oxide catalyst showed the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 18.1°, 28.9°, 32.3°, 36.1°, 38.3°, 44.6°, 51.1°, 58.8°, 60.2° and 64.9°, corresponding to the crystal phases of Mn3O4 [35]. As shown in Fig. A4, no species related to the interaction between the MCM-41 support and metal oxides were observed by XRD, according to the comparison of different catalysts (Co3O4, Mn3O4, MCM-41, 50wt% Co3O4@MCM-41 and 50wt% Mn3O4@MCM-41). The above results suggested that the active components in the Co- and Mn- based catalysts should be Co3O4 and Mn3O4, respectively. Moreover, for the unsupported metal oxide catalyst of Co2MnO4 (Fig. 1b), the diffraction peaks of the Co2MnO4 species was also identified [35]. Fig. A5 shows XRD patterns obtained from the catalysts of xCo2MnO4@MCM-41 with different metal oxides loading (x = 5 ∼100 wt%). It was found that the diffraction intensity was positively correlated with the loading of metal oxides. To understand the states of the metal oxides in the catalysts, the XPS analysis was conducted. As shown in Fig. 2 a, all cobalt-containing catalysts exhibited the asymmetrical Co 2p3/2 profile. These spectra can be decomposed into two spin-orbit doublets of Co3+ and Co2+ around 780.4 eV and 782.2 eV respectively, together with a weaker satellite peak near 786.5 eV [35]. Based on the fitting of the XPS spectra, the molar ratio of Co3+/Co2+ for the bimetallic oxide catalyst of 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 was 1.4, which was lower than the value of 1.9 for the single metal oxide catalyst (10wt%Co3O4@MCM-41). As shown in Fig. 2b, the Mn 2p3/2 spectra can be deconvoluted into two spin-orbit doublets around 641.4 eV and 643.4 eV, belonging to the Mn 2+ and Mn3+ peaks respectively [35]. The molar ratios of Mn3+/Mn2+ obtained from the 10wt%Mn3O4@MCM-41 catalyst and 10wt%Co2MnO4@ MCM-41 catalyst were 2.0 and 1.1, respectively. Generally, the binding energy in the XPS analysis depends on various factors, such as element type, electron occupied orbit, element chemical valence and electron shielding effect [35–37]. According to previous research, the binding energy of Co3+ is lower than that of Co2+ [35–37]. Moreover, the morphological structure of the catalysts was investigated by the transmission electron microscope (TEM). The typical TEM image from the 10wt%Co2MnO4@ MCM-41 catalyst exhibited the nonuniform distribution of scattered punctiform (Fig. 2c). The average sizes of the metal oxides evaluated by TEM were summarized in Table 1. The size of the bimetallic oxide (like Co2MnO4 in 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41catalyst) was smaller than that of the single metal oxide (like Co3O4 in 10wt% Co3O4@MCM-41catalyst). Fig. A6 shows the TEM images obtained from the catalysts of Co2MnO4@MCM-41 with different metal oxides loading. The size of metal oxide increased with the increase of the metal oxide loading (Table A2 in Supplementary Material). This may suggest the particle aggregation occurring at high loading of the metal oxide [36]. 3.2 Catalytic transformation of xylan into toluene intermediate 3.2.1 Performance of different zeolite catalysts for production of toluene intermediate Toluene is the key intermediate for the synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid. Firstly, the catalytic performances of different zeolite catalysts for the selective catalytic cracking of xylan to toluene intermediates were compared. As shown in Fig. 3 , the metal oxide-modified catalysts have a certain influence on the yield of total aromatics and the selectivity of the aromatic products. Among the tested catalysts, the 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst showed the maximum toluene yield with the highest toluene selectivity (Fig. 3). To clarify the role of each component in the composite catalyst (ZnO/HZSM-5), the performances of ZnO and HZSM-5 in the catalytic cracking of xylan were investigated (Fig. 3). In the absence of catalyst, no aromatic products were observed. When HZSM-5 was used, the aromatization activity of the catalyst was significantly enhanced. The acidity of the zeolite catalyst can be adjusted by varying the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of the zeolite catalysts (Table A1 in Supplementary Material). Fig. A7 shows the effect of the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of the zeolite catalysts on the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan. The yield of aromatics and toluene increased with the increase of acidity (corresponding to the decrease of the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio). This may suggest that strong acidity promoted the aromatization reactions in the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan. Based on the results of this work and previous work [8–11,28], the main functions of HZSM-5 in the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan are acid catalyzed deoxygenation and aromatization. As shown in Fig. 3, when ZnO was used, the products of aromatics and COx (x = 1,2) were observed. This indicated that ZnO had the catalytic activity for aromatization, decarbonylation and decarboxylation. In previous work, it has reported that the zinc-doped HZSM5 catalysts enhanced the aromatics yield for the catalytic aromatization of olefins [38], glycerol [39] or methanol [40]. Our recent work also showed that zinc oxide modified zeolite catalyst enhanced the formation of p-xylene in the bio-oil upgrading [28]. In this work, it was found that the zinc oxide-doped zeolite catalyst improved the yield of toluene (Fig. 3), which was attributed to that the introduction of ZnO into the zeolite promoted the aromatization reaction [28, 38-40]. 3.2.2 Effects of reaction parameters on production of toluene intermediate The effects of reaction conditions on the production of toluene intermediates in the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan were investigated by the selected 3wt%ZnO/HZSM5 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 4 , the addition of methanol in the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan significantly affected the product's distribution. Especially, it was found that the selectivity and yield of toluene were improved by adding methanol to xylan in the catalytic pyrolysis (Fig. 4). Previous studies also showed the overall yield of aromatics was promoted for the co-catalytic cracking of furan/methanol [30] or sawdust/methanol over HZSM-5 [41]. Recently, we found that the methanol addition in the bio-oil enhanced the p-xylene yield over the SiO2/HZSM5 catalyst [28]. Herein, the promotion of toluene yield by adding methanol can be attributed to two main reasons. On the one hand, the addition of methanol increased the molar ratio of hydrogen to carbon, reduced the coke yield and increased the yield of aromatics (Fig. A8 in Supplementary Material) [28,30]. On the other hand, the introduction of methanol was conducive to the methylation reactions of benzene to toluene, because the toluene selectivity increased and the selectivity of benzene decreased synchronously (Fig. 4). As shown in Fig. 4, both xylan and methanol can form aromatics through the aromatization reactions. Catalytic conversion of methanol to aromatics has been reported in previous work [30,33]. For the catalytic cracking of methanol, the yields of main products were 53.1 % aromatics, 8.9 % methane, 16.0% C2-C4 alkanes, 14.1% C2-C4 olefins, 4.5% CO, 0.2% CO2 and 2.6% coke. For the co-catalytic conversion of xylan/methanol (mass ratio = 1:1), the carbon balance was 99.4 %. The total toluene yield was 24.1 % with the 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst and xylan/methanol mass ratio of 1:1 at 580 °C. The majority of toluene (about 62.6%) came from methanol in the co-catalytic conversion of xylan/methanol (1:1). In addition, the reaction temperature had an important impact on the toluene yield and the product distribution in the xylan catalytic pyrolysis. As shown in Fig. 5 , the toluene selectivity increased as temperature rising from 450 to 580 °C, along with the decrease in the C8 + aromatic's selectivity. In general, high temperature is conducive to xylan's pyrolysis, deoxygenation, aromatization and cracking reactions, but the excess temperature also caused the dealkylation of toluene [30]. Therefore, the highest toluene yield was obtained at 580 °C, which may reflect the comprehensive influence of temperature on the above complex reaction processes. 3.3 Catalytic transformation of xylan-based toluene intermediate to benzoic acid 3.3.1 Performance of different metal oxide catalysts for synthesis of benzoic acid So far, various types of catalysts (such as metal oxides and metal complexes) have been employed for the oxidation of alkyl aromatics [22–26]. In this work, the catalytic oxidation performances of the different MCM-41-supported metal oxide catalysts in the oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid have been investigated. As shown in Table 2 , the catalyst supporter (MCM-41) showed a negligible catalytic activity for the toluene oxidation. Toluene conversion, selectivity and yield of benzoic acid depended on the types of the metal oxides. Regarding the single metal oxide catalysts, the Co-based catalyst exhibited higher toluene conversion and higher benzoic acid yield, compared to the Mn-, Fe- or V-based catalysts (Table 2). As shown in Table 2, the bimetallic oxide catalyst (like 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41) showed higher benzoic acid yield than single metal oxide catalysts, which may be attributed to the synergy effect of the bimetallic ions [42–44]. Compared to the single metal oxide catalysts, the selectivity of benzoic acid increased and the selectivity of intermediates (like benzaldehyde) decreased when using the bimetallic oxide catalyst. This suggested that the bimetallic oxide catalyst was conducive to the deep oxidation of intermediates. According to the XRD and XPS characterizations, the crystal structure and the valence state of the bimetallic catalyst (Co2MnO4) were different from those of the single metal oxide catalysts (Co3O4 and Mn3O4) (Figs. 1 and 2). The particle size of the Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst was smaller compared to the Co3O4@MCM-41 and Mn3O4@MCM-41 catalysts (Table 1). The synergistic effects of the bimetallic oxides have also been observed in previous work, such as the selective oxidation of m-xylene to isophthalic acid using AgWO3 catalyst [42] and the oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde over the CuCr2O4 catalyst [44]. Bimetallic catalysts may adjust the crystal structure, size and valence state of metal oxides through the interaction between the two metal ions, so as to improve the selectivity or yield of the target product [42–44]. In addition, the selectivity and benzoic acid yield were related to the loading amount of the metal oxides (Fig. A9 in Supplementary Material). When the loading was increased from 5 to 10 wt%, the conversion of toluene, selectivity and yield of benzoic acid increased. When the loading amount exceeded 20 wt%, the yield of benzoic acid showed a downward trend. In previous work, it was also observed that the activity of the catalyst with high loading decreased [36]. As shown in Table A2 and Fig. A6, the size of metal oxide increased with increasing the metal oxide loading. The reduction of activity for the catalyst with high loading amount may be due to the size increase of the metal oxide by the particle aggregation [36]. It was noted that metal oxide catalyst (like 10 wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41) showed lower toluene conversion in the benzoic acid synthesis without the initiator of n-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) (Table 2). By contrast, when a small amount of NHPI initiator (NHPI/PX=0.02) was added, the oxidation activity of the metal oxide catalyst was significantly improved. When oxygen or air is used as oxidant, it is usually necessary to add a small amount of initiator to promote the conversion of toluene [45,46]. In this work, low corrosive NHPI was used as initiator to improve the oxidation activity of toluene. Although n-hydroxyphthalimide itself has poor oxidation activity (Table 2), it can be used as an initiator to improve the oxidation activity by forming active radicals [45,46], as addressed in the Section 3.5 in detail. 3.3.2 Optimization of reaction parameters for synthesis of benzoic acid To obtain the optimal reaction conditions, the parameters (temperature, duration and oxidant's types) were investigated using the selected 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the catalyst showed low conversion of toluene at 20 °C, and the substrate conversion was enhanced incrementally, with temperature rising from 20 to 100 °C. The selectivity and yield of benzoic acid also increased with the rise of the temperature, while the selectivity of the intermediate products such as benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol decreased (Fig. 6b). The results suggested that higher reaction temperature was favorable for the oxidation of functional groups of methyl and aldehyde groups to carboxyl group in the benzene ring. Moreover, as the reaction duration was prolonged, both the selectivity and yield of benzoic acid appeared a monotonous upward trend (Fig. 7 ). As shown in Fig. 8 , the choice of oxidant has an important impact on the conversion of toluene and the selectivity of products. When the toluene oxidation was conducted using molecular oxygen as a oxidant, benzoic acid was the major prodcut and high toluene conversion was obtained over the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst at 80 °C for 4 h. In case of the air as an oxidant, the benzoic acid yield was lower than that using molecular oxygen, which was attributed to the lower oxygen content in the reaction mixture. With regard to hydrogen peroxide oxidant, the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst showed poor catalytic activity for the synthesis of benzoic acid. When tert-Butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) was employed as an oxidant, the main product became benzaldehyde, suggesting that the secondary oxidation of intermediates (like benzaldehyde) to benzoic acid was related to oxidant used. Thus, the selective oxidation of toluene to benzoic acid can be realized by using the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst and oxygen as a green oxidant under the mild heterogeneous catalysis condition (80 °C, 4 h). 3.3.3 Catalytic oxidation of xylan-derived aromatic intermediates to benzoic acid To produce bio-based benzoic acid, subsequently, the oxidation of the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates (1#) was tested at 80 °C for 2 h, which was obtained from the xylan catalytic transformation using the zinc oxide-doped zeolite catalyst at 580 °C (Fig. 3). As shown in Table 3 , the catalytic performance of the bimetallic oxide catalyst (10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41) was better than that of the single metal oxide catalyst in the synthesis of benzoic acid. This was consistent with the results of the catalytic oxidation of toluene model compound (Table 2). As shown in Fig. 9 a, benzoic acid was the major product formed from the selective oxidation of the xylan-based aromatic intermediates over the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM41 catalyst. A small amount of the by-products (like benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde) were also observed, corresponding to the catalytic oxidation of toluene in the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates. Besides, the minor products such as methylbenzoic acid, tricarboxybenzene and naphthaldehyde were derived from the oxidation of xylenes, trimethylbenzenes and naphthalenes respectively, which contained in the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates. Only small amount of phenol was formed by the oxidation of benzene due to lower activity of sp2 C-H bond in benzene-ring compared to toluene [25,26]. Moreover, another aromatic intermediate 2#, derived from the distillation treatment of the xylan-based intermediate 1#, was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 9b, the intermediate 2# exhibited higher the selectivity to benzoic acid than using the intermediate 1# under the same reaction condition. The highest selectivity of 88.3 % benzoic acid with the substrate conversion of 90.5 % was obtained with the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst at 80 °C for 4 h. The above results show that the selective synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid can be realized through the oxidation of xylan-derived aromatic intermediates using the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst and oxygen as a green oxidant. In previous work, various homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts have been investigated for the catalytic oxidation of the sp3 C-H bond in toluene, such as metal complexes catalysts [22–24], metallic oxide catalysts [25,26], zeolite catalysts [18,27]. However, as far as we know, there was little report on the selective synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid using xylan. 3.4 Stability and reusability of catalyst in the synthesis of benzoic acid The stability and reusability of the 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst during xylan catalytic pyrolysis was tested under the optimal condition. As shown in Fig. 10 a, the catalyst deactivation leads to the decrease of the yield of the toluene intermediate. The activity of the deactivated catalyst can be partially recovered by burning coke with oxygen (Fig. 10a). As shown in Fig. 10b, the content of coke deposited on the catalyst was analyzed by TGA. The coke formation rate was about 66.5 ± 6.9 mg (gcatlyst × h)−1) catalyst under the optimal reaction condition. The TGA profile of the regenerated catalyst was nearly consistent with that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 10b). This indicated that the coke deposited on the catalyst used was able to be partly removed by the coke combustion. In addition, the changes of catalyst characteristics before and after the reaction have been investigated by XRD (Fig. A1) and NH3-TPD (Fig. A3). The specific surface area and total acidity for the catalyst used were lower than the values of the fresh catalyst (Table A1 in Supplementary Material). The catalyst used showed the dealumination compared to the parent zeolite (Table A1). Based on these characterization results, the deactivation of the zeolite catalyst in the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan was mainly attributed to coke deposited, dealuminization and the decrease of the acidity [47]. Moreover, the stability and reusability of the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst in the catalytic oxidation process of the aromatic intermediates was carried out under the optimal condition (Fig. 10c). After the each cycle reaction (four hours), the solid catalyst was recovered by the centrifugation, and used for the next cycle test. The conversion and selectivity of benzoic acid by using the recovered catalyst were not significantly decreased after five times of continuous reuse (Fig. 10c), suggesting that the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst had good stability in the process of the catalytic oxidation of the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates. The XRD pattern of the used 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst was almost the same as the pattern of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 10d), which further confirmed the good stability and reusability of the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst. 3.5 Possible reaction pathways for the bio-based benzoic acid synthesis In this work, the synthesis of benzoic acid from xylan involved two reaction steps: the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan and the catalytic oxidation of the aromatic intermediates (especially toluene). Toluene is a critical intermediate for the synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid. As shown in Scheme 1 , the possible pathways for the formation of toluene from xylan were proposed, based on this work and previous studies [8–11,28]. These reaction pathways mainly include xylan pyrolysis, deoxygenation of oxygenates, aromatization of olefins, dealkylation and polymerization of aromatics on the acid sites. The catalyst with low SiO2/Al2O3 ratio (or strong acidity) was conducive to the formation of toluene (Fig. A7). The ZnO -doped zeolite catalyst improved toluene yield (Fig. 3), which was attributed to that the introduction of ZnO into zeolite promoted the aromatization reaction [28,38–40]. According to our previous work [28,30,47] and other literatures [2,48], low-carbon olefins (especially C2-C4 olefins) are important precursors for the formation of aromatics in the catalytic pyrolysis of biomass or its derivatives. Generally, low-carbon olefins can be converted into mixed aromatics (such as benzene, toluene and xylene) through the process of olefin aromatization in the presence of acidic sites of zeolite catalysts [2,28,30,47–50]. It has been proposed that the aromatization of olefins on the acid sites undergoes the following main reaction steps [49,50]. Firstly, low-carbon olefins are polymerized on the acid sites to form high-carbon olefins (especially C6 + olefins). Then, high-carbon olefins are cyclized to form aromatic precursors (like the precursor of six-membered ring). Finally, aromatics precursors are dehydrogenated on the acid sites to produce aromatics such as benzene, toluene and xylene. As shown in Scheme 1, the addition of methanol into xylan promoted the methylation reactions of benzene to toluene (see Fig. 4) [30]. Co-catalytic conversion of xylan and methanol was also conducive to increase the molar ratio of hydrogen to carbon, reduce the coke yield and increase the aromatics yield (Fig. A8 in Supplementary Material) [28,30]. In addition, methanol itself can also form aromatics through the methanol to olefins (MTO) and subsequent olefin aromatization reactions (Fig. 3) [30,33,49]. Besides, the selective oxidation of the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates (especially toluene) is another important step for the synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid. To further understand the oxidation characteristics of the aromatic intermediates, we investigated the oxidation reactions of the typical model compounds using the catalyst of 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 (Fig. A10 in Supplementary Material). The catalytic conversion of benzene exhibited low conversion. Phenol was the main product in the benzene oxidation. Unlike benzene oxidation, the catalytic oxidation of toluene showed much higher conversion (96.3 %) than that of benzene under the same reaction condition, indicating that the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst had high oxidation activity of the side-chain oxidation of toluene. The products from the catalytic oxidation of toluene were predominantly composed of benzoic acid (selectivity: 97.9 %) together with a small amount of benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol. The catalytic conversion of C8 aromatics (like p-xylene) also showed high conversion using the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst. Terephthalic acid and p-toluic acid were two main products in the p-xylene oxidation, together with a small amount of by-products such as p-tolylaldehyde, p-toluyl alcohol, and 4-carboxybenzaldehyde. The catalytic oxidation of bicyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (like methyl naphthalene) produced complex products such as 2-naphthalenecarboxylic acid, 2-naphthaldehyde, 2-naphthalenemethanol and 2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone (Fig. A2). The above results indicated that the catalytic activity for the side-chain oxidation of alkyl aromatics was higher than that for the oxidation of benzene ring when using oxygen as an oxidant and the metal oxide catalyst. This could be attributed that the dissociation energy for the sp3 C-H bond in the side-chain of the alkylaromatics is lower than that of the sp2 C-H bonds in the aromatic ring [25,26]. It was noticed that benzoic acid was the major product from the oxidation of the xylan-derived aromatic intermediates using the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 9). When using oxygen as an oxidant and metal oxide as a catalyst, the reaction mechanism of the toluene oxidation has been generally considered as the radical chain reaction processes, as proposed by previous studies [20,26,45,46]. Based on the study of the model compounds in this work and previous studies [20,26,45,46], the possible reaction pathways and reaction mechanism for the toluene oxidation to benzoic acid is presented in Scheme 1. For the initiation step, the phthalimide N-oxy radical (PINO radical) formed from the initiator of n-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) through hydrogen abstraction on the metal oxide catalysts [45,46]. Then, the PINO radical abstracts a hydrogen atom from the methyl in toluene, forming another radical of C6H5CH2* and NHPI [45,46]. The oxygen molecule inserts into the C6H5CH2* species to generate a peroxy-radical C6H5CH2OO*, followed by reacting with toluene to form C6H5CH2OOH intermediate [45,46]. The intermediate of C6H5CH2OOH can react with toluene to form benzylic alcohol (C6H5CH2OH) [45,46]. The intermediate product of benzaldehyde (C6H5CHO) may come from two reaction pathways: the dehydration of the C6H5CH2OOH intermediate and the oxidation of benzylic alcohol [45,46]. Finally, benzaldehyde can be further oxidized to the final product of benzoic acid [45,46]. 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel approach for the synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid (an important high-value chemical in petrochemical industry) has been developed. This transformation was realized by the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan to toluene intermediate and subsequent catalytic oxidation to benzoic acid. (1) For the catalytic pyrolysis of xylan, the strong acidic catalyst was conducive to the formation of toluene intermediate. The zinc oxide-doped zeolite catalyst enhanced the aromatization reaction and improved the toluene yield. The addition of methanol into xylan promoted the methylation reactions of benzene to toluene. The total toluene yield of 24.1 % was obtained over the selected 3wt%ZnO/HZSM-5(25) catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions: catalyst/xylan mass ratio of 3:1, xylan/methanol mass ratio of 1:1 and 580 °C. Both xylan and methanol can form aromatics through the aromatization reactions. According to the yield of toluene, about 62.6% of toluene came from methanol in the co-catalytic conversion of xylan/methanol (1:1). (2) For the catalytic oxidation of the aromatic intermediates, the bimetallic oxide catalyst of 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 exhibited more superior performance than that using the single metal oxide catalysts, which may be due to the synergy effect of the bimetallic ions. The results of the catalyst characterizations suggested that the active components in the bimetallic oxide catalyst were the divalent/trivalent cobalt and manganese ions. The selectivity of benzoic acid was 88.3%, and the maximum yield of benzoic acid was 19.2% (based on xylan) using the bimetallic oxide catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions (80 °C, 4 h). (3) The deactivation of the zeolite catalyst during xylan catalytic pyrolysis was mainly attributed to coke deposited, dealuminization and decrease in acidity. The activity of the deactivated catalyst can be partially recovered by burning coke with oxygen. The 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst had good reusability in the catalytic oxidation process. (4) The possible reaction pathways for the synthesis of bio-based benzoic acid were proposed based on the study on the catalytic conversion of the model compounds and the characterizations of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The efficient synthesis of bio-based chemicals using renewable carbon resources is of great significance to promote sustainable chemistry and develop green economy. This work aims to demonstrate that benzoic acid, an important high added value chemical in petrochemical industry, can be selectively synthesized using xylan (a typical model compound of hemicellulose). This novel controllable transformation process was achieved by selective catalytic pyrolysis of xylan and subsequent catalytic oxidation. The highest benzoic acid selectivity of 88.3 % with 90.5 % conversion was obtained using the 10wt%Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions (80 °C, 4 h). Based on the study of the model compounds and catalyst's characterizations, the reaction pathways for the catalytic transformation of xylan to bio-based benzoic acid were proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Selective catalytic synthesis of bio-based high value chemical of benzoic acid from xylan with Co2MnO4@MCM-41 catalyst
